ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned that grades don't reflect how much you know in the subject.
A lot of knowledge about social phenomena, how to explain societal structures. Gained insight into the history of the field as well.

I learned so much about how psychology is seen in every day life in our relationships and experiences. I gained more knowledge about persuasion, relationships, leadership and power, attraction, and prejudice. There was a lot covered in each lecture. Learned how to carefully read a psychology paper and parse out the information. Also learned how social influence appears in our every day lives.
How to apply social psychology to present day social issues, how to read psychological research papers
Basic psychological concepts associated with society and how others influence our own behavior
knowledge of topics like the self, emotions, relationships, attraction, persuasion, social influence, bias and racism
I learned how a lot about research studies.
Social skilllsssss
Some social psychology concepts
I developed very interesting insights into the psychology behind social interactions.
How to read psych research papers and form an educated opinion on the research
I learned about psychology in a broader context

I learned so many new terms and concepts when it comes to social psychology.  I also learned how to analyze articles through a psychological lens and how to apply the concepts I learned in class assignments.
basic understanding of social psychology terms and studies. would not recommend if you've already taken an introductory psychology course.

Social psychology principles, experimental methods and motivations, applications, social influence, attitude and changing attitude, emotion theory, attraction and relationships, pier and influence, diversity
General information regarding human behavior based on social emotions and social needs.
Learned a lot about human behavior in social and strategical situations.
How to reflect critically on psychological publications, how to produce creative and persuasive pieces of media, how to convince people you are worthy of entrance to a selective institution/show etc.
Very boring class
I developed an understanding of the important concepts and theories in social psychology as well as insight on how social psychological research is conducted and can affect the world.

I gained a deep insight into how humans approach socialization, along with the many facets of what socialization entails. This course has helped me understand why humans behave the way they do, especially behaviors that I encounter daily.

Through this course, I was able to develop my ability to think about the human in a social context - an approach to psychology applicable to the world and often connected with my day-to-day experiences. I also developed my ability to read scientific papers and draw concepts from research studies.
I developed an understanding in psychology and learned to apply the concepts discussed in class to real-life situations.
I learned about a lot of studies and theories in social psychology. I also learned about stuff that is important for today; like how policing is racist.
There's no point in our lives where we aren't social actors.
This was a great intro into the world of social psychology. I loved all the different creative types of assignments that we had, I thought they were really helpful in immersing me into the concepts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: Hirsch is a great lecturer. Weakness: Hirsch is an overly harsh grader. Way too harsh. You get more focused on grades than actually learning. Not a fan at all.

Strengths: Very well explained content with comprehensive slides. Good examples used throughout to strengthen ideas.
Weaknesses: None.
The biggest weakness has to be the number of assignments.
Good study examples each lecture that related to the topic and showed how it played out in the real world. Good amount of assignments that weren't overbearing.

Strengths: Engaging lectures, open note tests, fun assignments

Weaknesses: Location (I don't like Loria center)
I really appreciated the flexibility provided by the professor in terms of how students can engage with the course
strengths: lectures are interesting, virtual option was good for covid, manageable workload, assignments really help build for exams
I wish the course did more real life applications.
I think the location of the class is bad, especially with the timing. It was hard to make an person class. I also think that some material should be explained more clearly.
This course is fairly easy but it's a bit boring and basically offers terms for common sense

STRENGTHS: not many honestly, this class quickly became my least favorite this semester and was overall a drag to get through

WEAKNESSES: HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE COMMUNICATION AND CLARITY ABOUT GRADING. The entire semester there were assignments (the reading responses) which should have just been easy, give-me points that were so, SO ANNOYINGLY NIT PICKILY GRADED. I consistently was not enjoying any of the assignments in this class not because of difficulty or lack of interest, but rather that I was constantly scanning my work and worried about losing points for not doing things a particular way.

strengths - very informative, interesting, great use of studies as examples of phenomena
weaknesses - a lot of information in a relatively short amount of time, at times overwhelming
The class was well adapted to be both in person and virtual, which I greatly appreciate in terms of accessibility.
The material was interesting but I think if we went over more textbook concepts before using case studies that would be helpful
A strength was definitely the professor and the way she facilitated the class. A weakness was that it didn't feel like all the students were fully engaged in the course.

Strength was the clear slides and professor's knowledge of the course. I personally found the lectures quite numbing, only 15 of the 60 plus kids enrolled showed up to lectures. The experiments explained connected with the topics, but it just wasn't my cup of tea I guess.

Assignments and readings were good.

Could have more knowledge check ins - maybe jn the form of weekly quizzes, etc

Strengths: Professor is a great lecturer
Weaknesses: No discussion section and the content can get a little repetitive (lectures could probably be cut short into 50 mins, twice a week)
Very interesting content with fun assignments.

Strengths:
Professor Hirsch!!!
She's so clear in her lectures; her powerpoints and examples are amazing too. She somehow manages to find the most relevant research studies, and the way she covers topics that are relevant and organized thematically is just fantastic. 
I loved this class so much that I would constantly tell my friends about interesting facts I learned from lectures / from the readings.
Professor Hirsch is also mostly receptive to feedback and incorporates it into the class structure. 
Finals and midterms were open book open notes, which was great too because it made studying far less stressful since we didn't have to memorize 5000 studies and researcher names.

Weaknesses:
I wish there were more late days
I did pretty well on the final and midterm, but I do think some of the short-answers questions (especially in the midterm) could have been phrased less ambiguously. 
No sample reading response answers given, which made navigating the assignment a little tricky
I like the professor but very basic content so it bored me a lot
This course is taught very well (Prof. Hirsch), and it covers a lot of interesting material in a non-repetitive manner.

Strengths: open note tests
Weaknesses: too much content on tests to finish on time
Less variation in types of assignments.

Strengths: I really love Professor Hirsch's lectures. She has kept me engaged and truly conveys the information effectively. She explains the content in a clear manner.

I do not have any weaknesses to report.
Grading for the reading responses was not clear at all. There was no clear way to improve. It often felt like your grade was dealt to you by the roll of a dice. The grading was rather inconsistent.

While I found the lectures incredibly interesting, they verged on being a little too long oftentimes. I think if they were cut down into 50 min lectures, the engagement with the course would be much higher. I also think that having more in-class activities would facilitate more class engagement.
This course was good in lecture style and consistently brought in guest speakers.

Strengths: Professor Hirsch is a great lecturer and she is passionate about it! She is also a caring professor who just wants the best for her students! You also get a good, broad overview of a lot of topics in social psychology. 
Weaknesses: Assignments do not prepare you for the exams! So, the midterm felt like a curveball and was difficult to finish. There were a lot of questions and the short answer questions were crazy hard, so the lack of prep for them was not great.

- Strengths: Dr. Hirsch is a great lecturerher public speaking abilities are unmatched
- Weaknesses: it was easy (and sometimes convenient) to skip class
Strength: the professor was a great communicator and lecturer. Weakness: I found the grading to be a little inconsistent.

I really liked having the more creative assignments, and open book exams, I thought all of that were very perfectly conducive to my learning. But it did feel sometimes like there was just one thing after another, with only one grace day, so it could feel a little overwhelming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. Hirsch is an overly harsh grader. Way too harsh. You get more focused on grades than actually learning. Not a fan at all.
Yes, if you're interested in learning about society and intuitive, detailed explanations of attitudes, biases, etc.
No, the professor was terrible. The content was bland, and generic. Overall terrible course.

Yes absolutely, especially if Professor Hirsch is teaching. She did a great job in capturing the lectures and making them accessible for everyone. Each day I learned something new, and the assignments were easy to follow and get good grades on.

Yes. I thought the course was very well-taught, and not too difficult. It was very low stress, compared to other psych credits at Yale, and I found a lot of the material very applicable to my daily life.
Fun, chill, low pressure introductory psychology class!
yes as a fifth class
Yes
Maybe
Yes. Pretty easy and chill gut.

ABSOLUTELY NOT, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS WITH HIRSCH UNLESS YOU ARE A PSYCH MAJOR AND DESPERATELY NEED A SOCIAL PSYCH REQUIREMENT. 

Where do I even begin with this class. FIRST: IT IS A BIG LECURE PSYCH CLASS AT YALE with NO. CURVE. So don't expect The first one that I've heard of. And as the icing on the cake, the grade cutoffs are harder (93, 83, 73 etc rather than 92 82 . . . ) than average. 

But, hey, no curve would be fine if the assignments were graded fairly and clearly. Nope. The reading assignments, which were so, so annoying to complete, consisted of doing some very easy questions where points were easy to gather, and then a larger, open-ended portion which if you lost 2 points on you would be at an A- or a B+ for the assignment. The instructions for this portion were vague (share your ciritical thoughts) but graded super harshly. When I asked a TF about this, I was told that an A- was supposed to be the modal grade for the homeworks and that I should worry more about the exams as they were more important for my grade. 

Speaking of which, the exams were terribly planned, and basically consisted of you throwing up a bunch of citations to studies instead of actually writing anything salient or novel. 

Lecture was a drag to get through, and basically consisted of listing definitions from the textbook and reiterating the same concepts from the readings. Even at 2x speed lecture felt slow. I say this because practically no one showed up in person for lecture (for good reason, because it was so boring and not engaging in the slightest) which was even acknowledged by prof. Hirsch in class multiple time. In an 100 person class, maybe 10 people consistently showed up by mid semester. 

To top it all off, Prof. Hirsch realized some of these short-comings and encouraged all of us to fill out midterm review surveys after the first midterm had more variability than she expected (probably because she did not properly explain that we would have to list 2 studies per answer on multiple of the midterm short answer sections). Instead of taking the criticisms that the students brought to her at heart--that the grading was opaque and harsh, that lecture was slow and not engaging, etc. she defensely wrote a class-wide email saying that the grading was not the TF's fault and that they were simply "doing what she told them to do". Great. The issue wasn't the TFs, IT WAS YOUR OPAQUE, UNCLEAR GRADING GUIDELINES THAT WERE SO STRICTLY FOLLOWED THAT MADE US STUDENTS WANT TO TEAR OUR HAIR OUT. I am so glad this class is over. Avoid this class at all cost.

Yes, the material was very interesting and obviously applicable to real-world experiences, so I would consider it beneficial. However, the grading mechanisms were rather strict and did not particularly provide great feedback to facilitate error-correction and understanding.
Yes, if someone is interested in psych this is a great intro course.
I think the material was interesting but would recommend only if they were interested in more creative assignments
I would definitely recommend this course if you're interested in psychology. Lectures and assignments are both engaging and interesting and the professor is great.
Meh. Probably look into what other psychology courses are offered.
Yes! Great intro psychology class and covers a bunch of social psychology concepts in non trivial depth
Yes, if they are interested in gaining general psychology knowledge.
Yes. Definitely a gut, the content is interesting, the assignments are fun and relevant, and the professor has so much energy and cares a ton about the mental health of her students.

Yes!!
Top 2 classes I have taken at Yale. 
Prof Hirsch's lectures are amazing.
The assignments are so fun and interesting and none took me longer than a couple of hours to complete (the persuasion assignment did take me a day or two but that was because I chose a harder piece of media as my format). 
The material itself is fascinating and gives you great insight into your own social life.
no, boring content
This is a great course if youre interested in psychology, social interactions, group dynamics, attitudes, persuasion, etc.
this class has rubrics for the assignments but unclear grading and unclear questions on the exams, the material is very basic, would not recommend
Yes this class was very interesting
Yes its a good introductory psychology class and the professor is good
Yes, this course is really interesting and would be great for students of all majors.

Yes, Professor Hirsch is interesting to listen to and a great lecturer. However, I think that she should do away with the prerecorded option for lecture. Nobody would come and the classroom was often empty. I would go every time and watch the number of attending students dwindle.

I would! The class taught me a lot about people, how they think, how they tend to behave. What I learned in the class has stuck with me, and I oftentimes reference it with my friends outside of the class.
Yes, it is a very applicable class to everyday life.
Yes, if you are a psych major or want to learn about social psychology. Don't take is as a gut, though because there are readings and the assignments take some time to do, but are fun!
Yes
Definitely! I had a great experience in this class and everyone can learn something from the course material that would be useful to their lives at this point in time.
Yes absolutely. I loved the style of lectures and assignments and exams, and its also just a really interesting topic in the first place.
YES! The content and Professor Hirsch are so engaging. Can't speak highly enough of the course.
